Text description: 20 brushed DC motors. Tendon-driven. Shadow Tactile Sensing (STF) with magnets and 3-axis Hall effect sensors on index and thumb (default). Motors stored in the hand base; tendons prone to wear with extensive use. Full ROS integration.
Notes: Given that we have it, is it backdrivable?

Text description: 15 DC motors. Tendon-driven. Distal tactile sensors (magnets and 3-axis Hall effect) with optional middle and proximal sensors. Modular finger and sensor design; motors stored in finger bases. Backdrivable. Full ROS integration.
12 motors. Quasi-Direct Drive (QDD). Tactile arrays (>100 points) on each finger. Thumb can be repositioned to pinky location for enhanced grip. Backdrivable. Supports Linux, SDK, and ROS.
16 DC motors. Gear-driven. Omnidirectional capacitive pressure-sensitive tactile sensors. Interchangeable fingertips for specialized grips. ROS support.
16 DC motors. Gear-driven. No built-in tactile sensing. Widely used for dexterity research. Supports Linux, Windows, and ROS.
Notes: Given that we have it, is it backdrivable?

Text description: 9 DC motors. Gear-driven (and spindle drives). No built-in tactile sensing. Features elastic gripping surfaces; power and control electronics integrated in the wrist. Supports ROS and Raspberry Pi.
Notes: Mentions nine drive motors in the operating manual. The function page says there is a servo motor connected to a spindle.

Text description: 6 brushless DC motors. Gear-driven. Tactile sensing via a flexible PCB and three barometric pressure sensors cast in silicone. Used in prosthesis and robotics; utilizes lightweight carbon fiber.
Unspecified number and type of actuators. Tendon-driven. Tactile sensing (type unspecified). The specifications are not finalized; planned to release in 2028.
6 DC motors. Gear-driven. Vision-based tactile sensors. The thin sensor profile reduces finger thickness and improves flexibility.

6 actuators (unspecified). Gear-driven. Force Sensing Resistor (FSR) in all fingertips. The index finger is touchscreen compatible and features a serrated fingertip texture for improved grip. Adapted from COVVI Prosthetic Hand. Compatible with ROS2 and Python ECI API.
5 brushed DC motors. Tendon-driven (with adjustable Bowden cable transmission). No built-in tactile sensing. Includes motor force/position sensors and optional tendon tension sensors.
3 motors. Geneva mechanism drive. Optional fingertip force sensors. Available in three variants: prosthesis, industry, and R&D. Compatible with ROS.
1 DC motor. Tendon-driven. No built-in tactile sensing. The fingers open and close together in one synergy; features interchangeable gloves. Compatible with ROS & ROS2.
2 DC motors. Tendon-driven. No built-in tactile sensing. Features dislocatable, self-healing finger joints and interchangeable gloves. Compatible with ROS and ROS2.
Notes: It does not specifically state tendon-driven but given that SoftHand is tendon driven, I have assumed tendon-driven

Text description: 20 brushless DC motors. Direct-driven. Optional fingertip Force/Torque (F/T) sensors. Optional shorter wrist. Suitable for research and industrial applications. Compatible with ROS2.
Notes: Claims each DoF (20) is independently driven but doesn't explicitly say if there are 20 motors.

Text description: Unspecified number of DC motors. Unspecified transmission type. Optional fingertip Force/Torque (F/T) sensors. Adaptive gripping capability: fingers can shift to form right hand, left hand, or gripper.
Unspecified number of brushless DC motors. Unspecified transmission type. Optional fingertip Force/Torque (F/T) sensors. Features a fully modular structure. Supports C/C++ and an SDK.
Unspecified number of brushless DC motors. Unspecified transmission type. No built-in tactile sensing. Offers optional suction-type fingertips.

8 smart actuators (type unspecified). Tendon-driven with Dyneema (Kevlar) tendons. Optional FTS pressure sensors (3 or 1 axis) and optional capacitive pads on the back of the palm. Features fingers with magnetic detachment. Open source ROS package.

6 smart actuators (type unspecified). Tendon-driven with Dyneema (Kevlar) tendons. No built-in tactile sensing. Features a Time-of-flight (ToF) distance sensor in the palm and optional capacitive pads on the back of the palm. Child-sized hand.

4 smart actuators (type unspecified). Tendon-driven with Dyneema (Kevlar) tendons. No built-in tactile sensing. Time-of-flight (ToF) distance sensor in the palm and optional capacitive pads on the back of the palm.

Unspecified number and type of actuators. Unspecified transmission type. Dynamic Tactile Array (DTA) capable of detecting up to 30N. Lifespan of over 1 million grip cycles. Backdrivable. Supports ROS, Linux, C++, Python, and Windows.
Unspecified number and type of actuators. Unspecified transmission type. 6-axis Force/Torque (F/T) sensors on each fingertip. For research use only.
6 miniature linear servo actuators. Linear-drive. Integrated force and tactile sensors. Two variants: BFX (greater speed) and DFX (greater grip force). Supports ROS.
6 miniature linear servo actuators. Linear-drive. 17 tactile sensors and 6 pressure sensors built-in. Fingertips can exert up to 3 kg.

4 brushless DC servo motors. Worm-drive and cable drive transmission. Optional torque and tactile sensing in fingertips; features a perception palm sensor that uses cameras, lasers, LED, and infrared to assist with object localization. Modular finger design.
6 servo motors. Linkage-driven. No built-in tactile sensing. Utilizes camera for AI image recognition, finger-guessing, etc. Integrated with Raspberry Pi 5.

Unspecified number and type of actuators. Unspecified transmission type. Optional tactile sensing. Features a modular finger design and optional independent thumb actuator. Compatible with C++, Python, and ROS.
Unspecified number and type of actuators. Unspecified transmission type. Unspecified tactile sensing. Part of the Figure 02 humanoid robot.
Unspecified number and type of actuators. Unspecified transmission type. Unspecified tactile sensing. Part of the Optimus humanoid robot.
6 micro linear servo motors. Linear-drive. 6 pressure sensors. Integrated with ROS (ROS2 Foxy).
Unspecified number of DC motors. Gear-driven. 94 tactile sensors in total. Backdrivable. Features a modular finger design.
Notes: 16 active DoF, I have been assuming that does not necessarily mean 16 motors.

Text description: 7 micro brushless DC motors. 6 Direct-drive, 1 gear-driven. 33 tactile sensors on fingertips, finger phalanges, and palm. Compatible with Unitree G1 humanoid robot.
Artificial muscle fibers (Myofiber technology). Unspecified tactile sensing. Clone has not publicly disclosed detailed information on Myofiber.

108 artificial muscle units. Unspecified number and type of actuators. Unspecified transmission type. Unspecified tactile sensing. Uses artificial muscles to achieve "infinite" degrees of freedom. A prototype.

Unspecified number and type of actuators. Hollow cup and Multi-link mechanism. Over 1000 ITPU multi-dimensional tactile sensing units covering the fingernails, fingertips, finger pads, and palm; featuring 15 types of tactile perception. Supports camera expansion on the palm and back of hand.
Unspecified number and type of actuators. Unspecified transmission type. No built-in tactile sensing. Used in inspection robots, prosthetics, and research. Supports SDK, ROS, and ROS2.
Unspecified number of motors. Tendon-driven. Equipped with position, force, and tactile sensors. Features independently replaceable fingers. Supports ROS and ROS2.
7 actuators (type unspecified). Unspecified transmission type. Tactile sensors on fingertips and cameras in the palm. Feature an articulated thumb joint. Part of the Atlas humanoid robot.
